comments: 5^n mod 12. - _Zerinvary Lajos_, Nov 25 2009Also continued fraction expansion of (5+3*sqrt(5))/10. - _Bruno Berselli_, Sep 30 2011From _Gary Detlefs_, May 19 2014: (Start)This sequence can be generated by an infinite number of formulas all having the form a^(b*n) mod c subject to the following conditions. The number a is congruent to either 5,11,13,17,21, or 23 mod 24 and b is of the form 2k+1.  1. If a = 5 mod 6 then c = 6  2. If a = 5 mod 8 then c = 8  3. If a = 5 mod 12 then c = 12  4. If a = 5 mod 24 then c = 24For example: a(n)= 13^(5*n) mod 8, a(n)= 29^(7*n) mod c where c is any number in {6,8,12,24}. (End)

formula: From _Paul Barry_, Jun 03 2003: (Start)  G.f.: (1+5*x)/((1-x)*(1+x)).  E.g.f.: 3*exp(x)-2*exp(-x).  a(n) = 3-2(-1)^n.  a(n) = 5^((1-(-1)^n)/2) = 5^(ceiling(n/2)-floor(n/2)). (End)a(n) = 5*(n mod 2)+(n+1) mod 2. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Oct 20 2006a(n) = 5^n mod 24. - _Paul Curtz_, Jan 09 2008a(n) = A000364(n+1) mod 10. - _Paul Curtz_, Feb 09 2010
